title: Why Be Afraid
description: Clipping details the  experience of a veteran who claims to have fought in two wars and begins discusssing the pervasive nature of terror and fear in the daily life of citizens in the face of major world wars and how God can alleviate that fear.

title: Scientists Discover 'Cement' of the Universe; Words as an Active Force In Daily Life; Musings of a Traveling Man

Robinson sent out literature asking people to use the God-Power to stop Hitler.

title: We Read an Amazing Story, Chapter 4 with Editors Corrections 2
description: Chapter 4 begins by expressing that many organized religions and reporters in national publications like Colliers and Time have misrepresented the message of Psychiana and Psychiana's doctrine. Chapter goes on to describe the origins of Psychiana and clarifies the nature of Christ, Psychiana's teachings, and God's Power here on earth. This draft of chapter includes editorial corrections in ink. Missing pages 140 - 150.
creator: Robinson, Frank B.
subject: God-Power; Psychiana Criticism; Psychiana Origins; God on Earth
publisher-digital: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives, http://www.lib.uidaho.edu/digital/

title: Out of this Chaos - What?
description: Twelve page typescript, written by Robinson during World War II, opens with the statement that a new civilization will be the result of the chaos war has created, but soon Robinson returns to his themes of the similarities between religions and ends the typescript with a description of the beginning of Psychiana.
creator: Robinson, Frank B.
subject: World War; Doctrine Parallels; Psychiana Origin; Psychiana Prophecies;

title: The Evolution of Religion
description: Typescript of an article on societal evolution in the face of what Robinson calls 'the threshold of the greatest spiritual awakening' in history. Robinson divides religion into exoteric and esoteric evolution, and discusses evolution in both categories.
creator: Robinson, Frank B.
subject: Origin of Religions; Sin; Sacrifice

title: Article and Response
description: Typescript begins with an article from the Kansas City Star. Robinson follows this article with a response accusing the writer, a Methodist minister, of apologizing for his beliefs and 'poking fun at science.' Robinson asserts he would never apologize for his beliefs in Psychiana.
creator: Robinson, Frank B.
subject: Science and Technology; Methodists
publisher-digital: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives, http://www.lib.uidaho.edu/digital/

title: Being Big
description: Typescript of an article begins with an anecdote of a woman in Robinson's home who says she can't get into the Christmas Spirit. Robinson uses this as a platform to discuss that he would play his own hymns in his own home regardless of the nature of the holiday or his guests religious beliefs. He asserts, in his home, other beliefs are not true.
creator: Robinson, Frank B.
subject: Christmas; Freedom of Religion
publisher-digital: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives, http://www.lib.uidaho.edu/digital/

title: The World Under God
description: Typescript of an article begins with Robinson asking a question,'What will the world be like if the knowledge of the Spirit of God is universal?' Robinson discusses the impacts of war and equates the fight for beliefs to a religious war.
creator: Robinson, Frank B.
subject: World War II; Religious War; Spirit of God

title: The New Revelation of God
description: Typescript of an article on what Robinson claims happens to a member of Psychiana after they eliminate the fear of sin impressed upon them by orthodox religions and begin to realize the power of the Spirit of God in their own lives. Robinson uses testimonials from Psychiana Students.
creator: Robinson, Frank B.
subject: Spirit of God; Sin; Wealth and Success

title: Making Us Free
description: Typescript of an article begins with a quote from a Christmas card wishing Robinson a successful 50 years ahead. This prompts Robinson to state that if the Spirit of God isn't revealed to everyone in 10 years he will be disappointed. Robinson also discusses a plan to organize all religious leaders to talk.
creator: Robinson, Frank B.
subject: Religious Leadership; Psychiana Growth

title: 1938 National Convention Speech - Lecture 3
description: One of four lectures delivered at the 1938 National Convention. In lecture three Robinson promises to provide examples of the Power of the Spirit of God manifested in every living thing. He uses several examples, including a flower that will not grow in sawdust but will grow in dirt because of a cosmic order that governs every living thing. Another example is plants that will grow in one climate and not another, among several other examples.
creator: Robinson, Frank B.
subject: Spirit of God; God-Law; Examples of God-Law
publisher-digital: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives, http://www.lib.uidaho.edu/digital/
source: MG 101, Frank Bruce Robinson. Papers, 1929-1951, University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives

title: 1938 National Convention Speech - Lecture 4
description: One of four lectures delivered at the 1938 National Convention. In lecture four, Tenney begins by affirming that he will continue to support Psychiana and hopes to see a younger crowd. Robinson takes over, refuting accusations that he is an atheist. Robinson elaborates on how he differs from other orthodox religions on creed and dogma, but they all agree on the existence of God.
creator: Robinson, Frank B.
subject: Spirit of God; Psychiana Criticism
publisher-digital: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives, http://www.lib.uidaho.edu/digital/

title: The Living Among The Dead
description: Typescript of an article discussing the nature of the infallibility of all orthodox religions. Robinson argues if they all claim to be right, then they may all be false. Robinson uses a biblical quote--'Why seek ye the living among the dead?'--to claim these religions believe in 'dead gods,' particularly those that are crucified.
creator: Robinson, Frank B.
subject: Crucified God; Bible Criticism; Criticizing Orthodox Reilgions
publisher-digital: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives, http://www.lib.uidaho.edu/digital/

title: Surrounded by God
description: Typescript of an article begins with the example of goldfish swimming in water, which allows them to live. Robinson uses this as a metaphor for the Spirit of God around us and goes on to explain how this power works on earth.
creator: Robinson, Frank B.
subject: Spirit of God; God on Earth
publisher-digital: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives, http://www.lib.uidaho.edu/digital/

title: The Pioneer, Chapter 1
description: The title for this 20 page typescript is taken from the first sentence in which Robinson states that man has a desire to pioneer into the unknowable Realm of God. It is a restatement of his belief in the God-Power, comparing contacting the 'Power' to the use of electricity in the home: flip the switch and it's there. This typescript also contains a reference to the Spirit of God as the 'Flame'
creator: Robinson, Frank B.
subject: Spirit of God; God-Power
publisher-digital: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives, http://www.lib.uidaho.edu/digital/

title: Getting Used to God
description: Typescript of an article discussing the difference, according to Robinson, between recognizing the Spirit of God and the ability to use it in order to draw on its power. Robinson then digresses, admittedly, to claim that Psychiana grows as it refutes other religions' doctrines that believers live apart from God.' [1 of 49 lead articles apparently written for publication in Psychiana Weekly]

subject: Spirit of God; Psychiana Growth; Criticizing Orthodox Reilgions

title: The Secret
description: Typescript of an article begins with Robinson reporting criticisms of Psychiana, and refutes the validity of other religions based on the grounds of the 'crucified god' or dead god, as he calls it. Robinson uses a quote from Henry Ward Beecher, a minister, about connecting with the Spirit of God, as Psychiana teaches.

title: The Urge of the New
description: Typescript of an article in which Robinson details his prophesy of a time when no churches will exist in the world, but the world will be more 'Godly' than ever. Robinson calls this the Day of God and discusses what this day will be like.

subject: Day of God; Church in Decline; Psychiana Prophecies

title: In the Public Interest
description: Typescript of an article discussing the resistance churches and orthodox religions will have to the teachings of Psychiana. Robinson regards Psychiana as his 'great responsibility' and expresses his fear that the 'world of religion' will oppose him in his teachings.

title: Keep Your Eyes Open
description: Typescript of an article responding to three other articles reporting on a reformation within the Catholic Church in America. Robinson uses these articles to discuss falsities he finds in Catholicism and accuses it of being 'the greatest system of  paganism and idolatry in the world today.'

title: Losing Ones Faith

title: Spirit Control
description: Typescript of an article in which Robinson defines what he calls 'Spirit Control,' the ability to control the Spirit of God once you have realized it lives in and throughout you. Robinson discusses the benefits and conditions under which one lives their life once they realize they have 'Spirit Control.'

title: Good News - Purpose of the Program
description: Radio program episode outlines the purpose of the 'Good News' radio program, to broadcast positive and peaceful things rather than negative. Episode includes organ music and songs sung by Al Marino, jokes made in the face of war, and urges listeners to buy quality-made products for better piece of mind.

title: Comprehending the Deity
description: Typescript of an article responding to a quote from Don D. Tullis on the nature of 'knowing God.' Robinson discusses the failure of Christianity to suggest that people cannot know or communicate with God, while Psychiana teaches that you can in fact know and talk to God directly.

title: Good News

Episode begins proclaiming the growth of Pyschiana and then takes listeners to Robinson's home in Moscow, Idaho, describing its appearance. A dialogue begins between a 'guide' and Robinson about miracles, healing, the God-Law, the mail Robinson receives, and the 'Life Impulse' or 'motivating spirit' that allows people to think and live with God.

title: Good News - Man's Quest
description: Radio program episode discusses man's quest for answers, then introduces Robinson and his concept of the Cosmic God-Power. Robinson discusses the God-Power, reads a student letter asking for help, and uses the discovery of the 'cosmic ray' by Professor Milikan as evidence that there is invisible power around us. Robinson claims this Power is for our use and can bring anyone what they desire. Also includes a testimonial from a man claimed to live in Holland.

title: Quiet Talks With God - Always Its God
description: Quiet Talks With God included a series of 101 newspaper columns written by Frank B. Robinson to communicate teachings of Psychiana. Column 61,'Always It's God,' addresses the Four Freedoms speech by Roosevelt and maintains that these goals are not possible without the power of God through man. This article is a typescript not formatted for newspaper columns.

title: Good News
description: Radio program corresponding with transcript Radio Psychiana - Series for Dr. Frank B. Robinson No. 4. Episode begins with 'guide' leading listeners to Robinson's house where Robinson plays his organ. Robinson uses a metaphor of being lost at sea and the term 'misfit' to describe those who don't have access to the God-Power. Robinson then reads testimonials from students who have acquired happiness and all the desires they seek by finding the God-Power, which Robinson stresses does not take long as shown by reading recent dates on the letters.

title: Psychiana No. 1
description: Fifteen minute radio broadcast begins with 'guide' asking general questions about Psychiana. Robinson asserts Psychiana can turn failure and into success, and uses how a radio works as an example of how knowing the God-Law allows people to 'tune in' to a great Power. Robinson also discusses what the God-Power is via the law that governs the cosmos and atoms.
creator: MacGregor & Sollie Studios
subject: Examples of God-Law; Atom; Science and Technology; Cosmos
publisher-digital: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives, http://www.lib.uidaho.edu/digital/
source: MG 101, Frank Bruce Robinson. Papers, 1929-1951, University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives

For other uses beyond free use, please contact University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department at libspec@uidaho.edu.

title: Psychiana No. 2
description: Fifteen minute radio broadcast. Broadcast begins with 'guide' and Robinson discussing what God is and the Christian orthodox definition of God and the stories of God. Robinson refutes orthodox stories of God as borrowed from each other. Robinson then discusses what God is to him and to Psychiana.
creator: MacGregor & Sollie Studios
subject: Doctrine Parallels; Criticizing Orthodox Religion; Supreme Intelligence; God-Spirit
publisher-digital: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives, http://www.lib.uidaho.edu/digital/
source: MG 101, Frank Bruce Robinson. Papers, 1929-1951, University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives

For other uses beyond free use, please contact University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department at libspec@uidaho.edu.

title: Psychiana No. 3
description: Fifteen minute radio broadcast. Episode begins with 'guide' and Robinson discussing the nature of miracles. Robinson refutes central Christian miracles like the crucifixion, resurrection, and the others as duplicated from other myths. Robins refutes heaven as a barrier created between us and God, but Psychiana affirms that we have access to all the things we want here and now on earth by communing with God and the God-Power.
creator: MacGregor & Sollie Studios
subject: Here and Now; Afterlife; Miracles; Doctrine Parallels; God-Power; Success; Material Abindance
publisher-digital: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives, http://www.lib.uidaho.edu/digital/
source: MG 101, Frank Bruce Robinson. Papers, 1929-1951, University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives
rights: Educational use includes non-commercial use of text and images in materials for teaching and research purposes. Digital reproduction permissions granted by University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department. For other uses beyond free use, please contact University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department at libspec@uidaho.edu.

title: Psychiana No. 4
description: Fifteen minute radio broadcast. Broadcast begins with 'guide' asking what it feels like when we commune with the God-Law, and admits feeling reservations about letting go of orthodoxy from childhood. Robinson affirms his unflinching stand against orthodox religions attacking him, and his feeling that orthodox religion did not satisfy his search for God.
creator: MacGregor & Sollie Studios
subject: Criticizing Orthodox Religion; Church in Decline; God-Law
publisher-digital: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives, http://www.lib.uidaho.edu/digital/
source: MG 101, Frank Bruce Robinson. Papers, 1929-1951, University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives

For other uses beyond free use, please contact University of Idaho Library Special Collections and Archives Department at libspec@uidaho.edu.

title: Psychiana No. 5
description: Fifteen minute radio broadcast. Broadcast begins with 'guide' asking one question about the afterlife and death. Robinson uses this question to call into question and refute central tenets of orthodox religious doctrine. Robinson discusses parallels of religious stories and ancient historians who fail to discuss Jesus Christ.
creator: MacGregor & Sollie Studios
subject: Criticizing Orthodox Religion; Afterlife; Doctrine Parallels; Jesus Christ; Ancient History
publisher-digital: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives, http://www.lib.uidaho.edu/digital/

title: Psychiana No. 6
description: Fifteen minute radio broadcast. Episode begins with 'guide' asking Robinson about the nature of the virgin birth. Robinson refutes the virgin birth ever happened for several reasons, specifically it defies the God-Law governing nature and the story was borrowed from heathen and pagan myths, which Robinson discusses in specific detail. Robinson also discusses who actually authored the Gopels.
creator: MacGregor & Sollie Studios
subject: Gospels; Doctrine Parallels; Virgin Birth; Paganism; Criticizing Orthodox Religion
publisher-digital: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives, http://www.lib.uidaho.edu/digital/

title: Psychiana No. 7
description: Fifteen minute radio broadcast corresponding with radio transcript Psychiana No. 7. Broadcast begins with 'guide' asking Robinson about the religious notion of sin, or the fall of man, and Robinson renounces these concepts, using the opportunity to talk about the origin of Christian and Pagan myths that have no basis in fact.

subject: Criticizing Orthodox Reilgions; Christianity; Paganism; Bible; Adam and Eve; Sin

title: Psychiana No. 8
description: Fifteen minute radio broadcast corresponds with radio transcript Psychiana No. 8. Episode begins with 'guide' asking Robinson about the Bible. Robinson points out there are many sacred books and nothing makes the Bible the sole sacred text. He argues that no proof exists that the evangelists are real and discusses more evidence against the validity of the Bible.

subject: Criticizing Orthodox Reilgions; Bible; Gospels

title: Psychiana No. 9
description: Fifteen minute radio broadcast corresponds with radio transcript Psychiana No.  9. Broadcast begins with a 'guide' asking Robinson questions and pontificating on the changing times due to advances in Science. Robinson and guide discuss Robinson's convention in Los Angeles and the many attendees who have been asked to believe what orthodox religions have told them is true. Robinson criticizes beliefs of organized religions like Christianity.

title: Good News - Historical Forces
description: Radio program episode that uses a student letter to begin discussing examples of forces that have existed all around us but have only been discovered in recent history, including electricity and radio waves. Instincts of animals, like birds, are also used as examples that there is a Law governing nature. Robinson discusses these examples as evidence of the unseen God-Realm and God-Law.

title: Psychiana No. 11
description: Fifteen minute radio broadcast corresponds with radio transcript Psychiana No.  11. Broadcast begins with 'guide' noting advances in Science and asking Robinson questions. Robinson uses a storm [cueing thunder sounds] to talk about the 'superstition' of storms as a sign of God's anger. He goes on to argue against myths of sacrifice prominent and common in many organized religions.

title: Psychiana No. 12
description: Fifteen minute radio broadcast corresponds with radio transcript Psychiana No.  12. title: The Shenandoah National Park

title: The Morning of Creation and 'Thoughts'
description: First Poem describes first days of creation and a conversation between God and man after man's creations and details the notion that man forgot the 'Creative Power' that God gave him throughout history; second poem describes the nature of the God-Power.

title: Who Can Explain?
description: Poem written by a Psychiana student that tells the narrative of a man who goes for a walk one nice day and is surprised by a light from the east that turns out to be the presence of God and Eternal Glory, which changes this person as a result.
creator: Sanford, Geo A.

title: Seven Poems
description: Several poems written by a Psychiana student asking questions about the strange want for earthly things like money juxtaposed with the real riches of family and knowing the true power of some natural force like a storm.

title: Untitled poem submitted by a student

title: A collection of poems by William Charles Williams, a Psychiana student
description: Several poems written by a Psychiana student listing a variety of concerns like age, growing old, and other issues that people worry about but that the poet finds trivial contrasted with poems about where the Power of God is located and that people can now walk with God on earth, or 'in the garden.'
